payload.instructions:
# Hearthlink Agent Team Manifest

This document defines the structure of the specialized AI agent team for the Hearthlink project. Each agent has a distinct role and is configured with a specific skill prompt from the `.claude/skills/` directory.

## Core Development Team

### 1. Specifications Planner
- **Role:** Gathers requirements, defines project scope, and produces detailed technical specifications (PRDs).
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/project-planner.md](./.claude/skills/project-planner.md)

### 2. System Architect
- **Role:** Designs the overall system architecture, including security, performance, and database structure.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/system-architect.md](./.claude/skills/system-architect.md)

### 3. Agent Architect
- **Role:** Specializes in the design of the multi-agent ecosystem, communication, and coordination.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/agent-architect.md](./.claude/skills/agent-architect.md)

### 4. Frontend Developer
- **Role:** Implements the UI/UX in React/TypeScript, focusing on accessibility and performance.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/hearthlink-frontend-dev.md](./.claude/skills/hearthlink-frontend-dev.md)

### 5. Backend Developer
- **Role:** Implements the core services and IPC architecture in Rust/Tauri.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/hearthlink-backend-dev.md](./.claude/skills/hearthlink-backend-dev.md)

## Specialist & Support Roles

### 6. UI/UX Design Specialist
- **Role:** Focuses on visual design, motion, and creating polished, intuitive interfaces.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/hearthlink-ui-ux-designer.md](./.claude/skills/hearthlink-ui-ux-designer.md)

### 7. DevOps Engineer
- **Role:** Manages CI/CD pipelines, build automation, and infrastructure.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/devops-engineer.md](./.claude/skills/devops-engineer.md)

### 8. Accessibility Specialist
- **Role:** Audits for WCAG compliance and ensures the application is inclusive.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/accessibility-specialist.md](./.claude/skills/accessibility-specialist.md)

### 9. Voice Integration Specialist
- **Role:** Designs and implements voice interfaces, speech recognition, and TTS.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/voice-integration-specialist.md](./.claude/skills/voice-integration-specialist.md)

### 10. Quality Validator (Code Reviewer)
- **Role:** Ensures code quality, test coverage, and requirement fulfillment through comprehensive code review and testing validation.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/code-reviewer.md](./.claude/skills/code-reviewer.md)

### 11. Documentation Scribe
- **Role:** Creates and maintains comprehensive documentation including API references, user guides, architecture docs, and code comments.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/documentation-scribe.md](./.claude/skills/documentation-scribe.md)

# Hearthlink Agent Team Manifest

This document defines the structure of the specialized AI agent team for the Hearthlink project. Each agent has a distinct role and is configured with a specific skill prompt from the `.claude/skills/` directory.

## Core Development Team

### 1. Specifications Planner
- **Role:** Gathers requirements, defines project scope, and produces detailed technical specifications (PRDs).

### 2. System Architect
- **Role:** Designs the overall system architecture, including security, performance, and database structure.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/system-architect.md](./.claude/skills/system-architect.md)

### 3. Agent Architect
- **Role:** Specializes in the design of the multi-agent ecosystem, communication, and coordination.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/agent-architect.md](./.claude/skills/agent-architect.md)

### 4. Frontend Developer
- **Role:** Implements the UI/UX in React/TypeScript, focusing on accessibility and performance.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/hearthlink-frontend-dev.md](./.claude/skills/hearthlink-frontend-dev.md)

### 5. Backend Developer
- **Role:** Implements the core services and IPC architecture in Rust/Tauri.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/hearthlink-backend-dev.md](./.claude/skills/hearthlink-backend-dev.md)

## Specialist & Support Roles

### 6. UI/UX Design Specialist
- **Role:** Focuses on visual design, motion, and creating polished, intuitive interfaces.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/hearthlink-ui-ux-designer.md](./.claude/skills/hearthlink-ui-ux-designer.md)

### 7. DevOps Engineer
- **Role:** Manages CI/CD pipelines, build automation, and infrastructure.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/devops-engineer.md](./.claude/skills/devops-engineer.md)

### 8. Accessibility Specialist
- **Role:** Audits for WCAG compliance and ensures the application is inclusive.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/accessibility-specialist.md](./.claude/skills/accessibility-specialist.md)

### 9. Voice Integration Specialist
- **Role:** Designs and implements voice interfaces, speech recognition, and TTS.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/voice-integration-specialist.md](./.claude/skills/voice-integration-specialist.md)

### 10. Quality Validator (Code Reviewer)
- **Role:** Ensures code quality, test coverage, and requirement fulfillment through comprehensive code review and testing validation.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/code-reviewer.md](./.claude/skills/code-reviewer.md)

### 11. Documentation Scribe
- **Role:** Creates and maintains comprehensive documentation including API references, user guides, architecture docs, and code comments.
- **Skill File:** [.claude/skills/documentation-scribe.md](./.claude/skills/documentation-scribe.md)
</INSTRUCTIONS>

# UI Recovery Plan

This document describes the next steps for recovering the legacy Hearthlink UI in an isolated workspace so it can be reviewed and iterated independently before re-integrating it into the main application.

## Objectives
1. **Isolated mock explorer:** Prepare a `ui-recovery` folder (either in the repo root or inside `frontend/`) that contains standalone React mockups for each recovered screen (Core, Alden, Alice, Mimic, Vault, Synapse, Email, Persona Council plus the legacy chrome wrappers). Each mockup should be runnable with its own entrypoint so you can spin up one screen at a time without the full app.
2. **Component scope & gaps:** For each recovered screen, include documentation (e.g., in `ui-recovery/README.md`) that lists:
   - Core layout and theme requirements (navigation, palettes, typography).
   - Which backend bridges or Tauri commands it depends on (AldenBridge, VaultBridge, etc.).
   - Current status (�?ostatic mock�??, �?oneeds IPC wiring�??, �?oneeds data cache�??).
3. **Standalone preview harness:** Provide a simple development harness (e.g., a small Vite/React setup or plain HTML + CSS) under `ui-recovery/` that lets you toggle between the mock screens, switch the �?oUnified�?? layout/theme, and inspect component-level styles without running the full Hearthlink build.
4. **Roadmap documentation:** Note the follow-up actions required to bring these mocks back into the main UI:
   - Hook Alden/Alice/Sentry commands to the appropriate Tauri bridges.
   - Replace the placeholder `LegacyComponentWrapper` components with their new versions.
   - Validate shared navigation chrome and theme tokens before merging.

## Next Session Prep
- When you open the next session, point me to the `ui-recovery` folder (once created) and describe which mock screen you want to iterate on.
- Provide any design assets or style tokens that need to be preserved so I can align the mockup theme with the recovered UI vision.
- Once the mockups look good, we can plan the actual migration back into `src/components` and re-enable the commented-out commands via `generate_handler_include.py`.

Let me know when you have the folder structure in place or if you want me to scaffold the first mock screen inside this workspace.

{"command":"@'
# UI Recovery Preview Workspace

This folder contains the isolated UI mockups described in `docs/ui_recovery_plan.md`. The `preview/` directory hosts a lightweight HTML/JS harness so you can launch each recovered module as its own page, switch between the unified vs. legacy chrome palettes, and inspect the component cards without running the full Hearthlink build.

## Launching the mockups
1. Open `ui_recovery/preview/index.html` in your browser (e.g., drag the file into Chrome or use `npx http-server ui_recovery/preview`).
2. Click any module card to open its dedicated preview page (`module.html?name=<moduleKey>`).
3. Use the “Switch theme” button to toggle between the unified (dark) and legacy (light) chrome palettes and confirm the CSS tokens cover both states.
4. Each module page shows layout calls, highlight cards, metric tiles, mock actions, and next-step notes so you can evaluate readiness.

## Module status at a glance
| Module | Layout / Theme | Dependencies | Current status & guidance |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Core Control | Unified charcoal + teal chrome; nav rail + workspace canvas + status ribbon. | NavigationBridge, SessionRegistry, PersonaStateCache | Static mock; needs IPC wiring + live persona cache before reintegration. |
| Alden Command Center | Legacy crimson + carbon gradient; transcript log + intent palette + note rail. | AldenBridge, VoiceProcessGateway, ClipboardBridge | Static mock; waiting on AldenBridge and voice channel toggling. |
| Alice Mirror | Violet gradients; mood timeline + policy checklist + reflection preview. | AliceBridge, PolicyRegistry, LoggingBridge | Static mock; policy-sync and reflection approvals need bridging. |
| Mimic Studio | Bright teal + slate; transcript explorer + behavior cards + export controls. | MimicBridge, MemoryGraph, PersonaRegistry | Interactive shell mock; still requires mimic bridge + memory graph data. |
| Vault & Secure Capture | Midnight blue + amber; secure grid + health panel + filters. | VaultBridge, EncryptionMonitor, MemoryIndexService | Static mock; needs VaultBridge heartbeat and encryption tokens. |
| Synapse Hub | Graphite + neon green; connector grid + timeline + threat radar. | SynapseBridge, TelemetryRelay, ThreatIntelligenceService | Static overview; telemetry refresh and bridge state still mocked. |
| Email Inbox | Paper white + amber; split inbox/composer with quick filters. | EmailBridge, PersonaRegistry, PriorityClassifier | Mock inbox + drafts; needs EmailBridge sync for real data. |
| Persona Council | Ivory + gold; persona gallery + goal matrix + policy queue. | PersonaRegistry, PolicyCatalog, GoalTracker | Static panels; persona metadata and policy queue require bridging. |
| Legacy Chrome Wrappers | Metallic grey chrome; header, footer utilities, and status lights. | LegacyComponentWrapper, ChromeTokens, CommandPalette | Static shell; ready to wrap each module once they rejoin the main UI.

## Notes for next sessions
- Hook the “Open preview” actions to the appropriate bridge (AldenBridge, VaultBridge, etc.) once the wiring exists so each mock action can surface real command payloads.
- Capture any updated tokens or spacing requirements from `docs/03_modules/*/ui_spec.md` before syncing the mock palette with the production chromes.
- After the mock look-and-feel is finalized, plan how to migrate the cards back into `frontend/src/components` and re-enable any commented-out `LegacyComponentWrapper` references using `scripts/generate_handler_include.py`.
- Keep this preview folder self-contained so reviewers can launch individual pages directly; share the path (`ui_recovery/preview/index.html`) in your next coordination note.
'@ > ui_recovery/README.md"}

payload.message:
## My request for Codex:
Do not make this UI live, do not connect anything.  Launch these mockups in a browser window for visible inspection only.

- The mockups live solely inside `ui_recovery/preview/` as static HTML/CSS/JS (see `index.html`, `module.html`, `styles.css`, and their supporting scripts) and don’t wire into any backend or bridge—nothing is connected or “live.”
- Open `ui_recovery/preview/index.html` in your browser (or via a lightweight HTTP server) to browse each module card, then click “Open preview” to launch any single-screen mockup; the “Switch theme” button only toggles CSS variables locally.
- No services are launched, no IPC calls are made, and every interaction remains purely visual so you can inspect the recovered chrome and layouts without triggering any logic.

I'm gathering precise single-line references for the new visual canvas section, CSS styles, and JS script additions to include in the final message. I want to highlight that these changes produce a static, visually enhanced UI mockup without live backend connections and remind that tests haven’t been run. The plan is to present these details succinctly in bullets mentioning `module.html:33`, `styles.css:292`, and `module-page.js:30`.

payload.message:
- Added a dedicated “Visual mock canvas” section so each module preview now renders a grouped set of stylized panels that hint at the layouts you’d see in the recovered interfaces, keeping the content purely descriptive but visually structured (`ui_recovery/preview/module.html:33`).
- Introduced new CSS rules for the module canvas panels plus animated placeholder strokes so the canvas feels more like a wireframe snapshot without ever hooking into any real data (`ui_recovery/preview/styles.css:292`).
- Updated the preview bootstrap script to populate the canvas panels from each module’s layout list, keep the action cards descriptive, and still display the status notes/metrics while leaving everything static and isolation-friendly (`ui_recovery/preview/module-page.js:30`).
- No tests were run (static mock-only update); you can keep opening `ui_recovery/preview/index.html` and each `module.html?name=<moduleKey>` in the browser for visual inspection only.

payload.text:
**Summarizing module features and gaps**

I'll prepare a final message that outlines each key module with its main features, referencing their source files and start lines, and then note precisely what the mock version lacks—especially around bridging, dynamic data, and interactivity—while framing the plan to bridge these gaps systematically.

payload.message:
- **Core project hub gap:** `ProjectsDashboard` (src/components/core/ProjectsDashboard.tsx:1) already drives real tabs (projects, Kanban, Gantt, risk matrix, resources), CoreBridge calls, modals, and live selection/creation flows; the preview only shows hero copy, static metrics, and placeholder action chips, so none of the actual boards, detail panes, forms, or IPC wiring exist in the mockup yet.  
- **Alden orchestration missing data flow:** `AldenCommandCenter` (src/components/alden/AldenCommandCenter.tsx:1) and the companion `EmailInbox` module (src/components/alden/EmailInbox.tsx:1) already connect to bridges, show tasks/events/email, manage modals, keyboard shortcuts, and sync commands; the mock only enumerates transcript highlights, intent palettes, and generic actions instead of those interactive panels, task/event modals, or EmailManager flows.  
- **Alice behavioral visuals:** `AliceDashboard` (src/components/alice/AliceDashboard.tsx:1) renders Recharts visualizations, fetches insights/profile via `AliceBridge`, and surfaces success/error feedback; the mock keeps just descriptive statements about a mood timeline and policy checklist without the actual bridge-driven charts or asynchronous state updates.  
- **Mimic persona operations:** `MimicDashboard` (src/components/mimic/MimicDashboard.tsx:1) already loads personas through `MimicBridge`, toggles actives, and opens the persona modal for editing; the visualization canvas in the mock doesn’t reproduce these toggles, sample exports, or bridge calls.  
- **Vault security interface:** `VaultDashboard` (src/components/vault/VaultDashboard.tsx:1) mixes search, create/edit/delete modals, knowledge-graph view, and AES-secured slices through `VaultBridge`; our mock only lists grid/filter ideas plus generic notes, so the secure capture grid, stats, and knowledge graph viewer are absent.  
- **Synapse observability:** `SynapseDashboard` (src/components/synapse/SynapseDashboard.tsx:1) already polls `SynapseBridge` for plugins, connections, and logs with toggle actions; the mock only mentions connector grids and radar graphics without hooking any of those live lists or controls.  
- **Persona Council/ chrome shells:** The real persona screens (e.g., `HubScreen` at src/components/personas/screens/HubScreen.tsx:1 and `RadialMenu` at src/components/personas/RadialMenu.tsx:1) invoke Tauri commands, show persona stats/traits, and expose navigation chrome; the mock’s descriptions and canvas panels don’t reproduce those radial menus or the persona status fetches.

Next step: line up each mock section with its corresponding existing component (e.g., point the Core hero at `ProjectsDashboard`, Alden at `AldenCommandCenter`/`EmailInbox`, etc.) and decide which parts of the real UI we can extract (layout elements, hero panels, sample data) to replace the current textual placeholders while keeping the preview static.

Let me create a detailed analysis: --- # COMPREHENSIVE QA REPORT: HEARTHLINK PERSONA UI SYSTEM **Date:** October 3, 2025 **Version:** 1.3.0 **Scope:** Hierarchical Navigation & Persona Interface System **QA Engineer:** Senior QA Review Agent --- ## 1. TESTING SUMMARY ### What Was Tested **Primary Components (9 files):** - `src/App.tsx` - Main application routing - `src/components/HierarchicalLaunchPage.tsx` - Launch screen with module navigation - `src/components/UnderConstruction.tsx` - Placeholder component - `src/components/personas/AldenInterface.tsx` - Alden persona UI - `src/components/personas/AliceInterface.tsx` - Alice persona UI - `src/components/personas/SentryInterface.tsx` - Sentry persona UI - `src/components/personas/MimicInterface.tsx` - Mimic persona UI - `src/components/personas/RadialMenu.tsx` - Navigation menu component - `src/components/personas/screens/` - HubScreen, CognitionScreen, DevelopmentScreen, InteractionScreen **Supporting Files:** - `src/lib/tauri-client.ts` - IPC client layer - `tailwind.config.js` - Theme configuration - `src/index.css` - Global styles and animations ### Testing Methodology 1. **Static Code Analysis** - Reviewed all TypeScript/TSX files for syntax, type safety, and patterns 2. **Component Structure Review** - Examined component hierarchy and data flow 3. **UI/UX Consistency Check** - Verified design system adherence 4. **Integration Readiness Assessment** - Evaluated Tauri IPC integration points 5. **Accessibility Audit** - Checked ARIA labels, keyboard navigation, screen reader support 6. **Performance Review** - Identified potential bottlenecks and optimization opportunities ### Overall Assessment **Status:** ⚠️ **BETA - REQUIRES CRITICAL FIXES BEFORE PRODUCTION** **Strengths:** - ✅ Consistent MythologIQ brand aesthetic (blue/gold, Orbitron font) - ✅ Well-structured component hierarchy with clear separation of concerns - ✅ Beautiful visual design with proper animations and transitions - ✅ Good foundation for Tauri IPC integration - ✅ Responsive layout with proper z-indexing **Weaknesses:** - ❌ Missing critical animations causing runtime errors - ❌ No error boundaries - app crashes will be catastrophic - ❌ All data is mocked with no real backend integration - ❌ Significant accessibility gaps (keyboard navigation, ARIA labels) - ❌ No loading states for async operations - ❌ Missing prop validation and TypeScript strictness - ❌ Code duplication across persona interfaces (96% identical) --- ## 2. BUGS & ISSUES FOUND ### CRITICAL Issues (Must Fix Before ANY Deployment) #### BUG-001: Missing Tailwind Animation Classes **Severity:** CRITICAL **Location:** Multiple files using `animate-float`, `animate-fade-in`, `animate-fadeIn` **Files Affected:** - `src/components/HierarchicalLaunchPage.tsx:185, 343` - `src/components/personas/AldenInterface.tsx:110, 116` - `src/components/personas/AliceInterface.tsx:110, 116` - `src/components/personas/SentryInterface.tsx:110, 116` - `src/components/personas/MimicInterface.tsx:110, 116` - `src/components/UnderConstruction.tsx:67` **Description:** Components reference animation classes (`animate-float`, `animate-fade-in`) that are NOT defined in `tailwind.config.js`. These classes exist in `src/styles/HearthlinkDesignSystem.tsx` but that component is never imported or used. **Reproduction:** 1. Launch application 2. Navigate to any persona interface 3. Open browser console 4. See warnings about unknown Tailwind classes **Recommended Fix:** Add to `tailwind.config.js`: ```javascript theme: { extend: { animation: { 'float': 'float 3s ease-in-out infinite', 'fade-in': 'fadeIn 0.5s ease-out', 'heartbeat': 'heartbeat 1.2s ease-in-out infinite', }, keyframes: { float: { '0%, 100%': { transform: 'translateY(0px)' }, '50%': { transform: 'translateY(-10px)' }, }, fadeIn: { '0%': { opacity: '0' }, '100%': { opacity: '1' }, }, heartbeat: { '0%, 100%': { transform: 'scale(1)', opacity: '0.6' }, '50%': { transform: 'scale(1.15)', opacity: '1' }, }, }, }, } ``` --- #### BUG-002: No Error Boundaries - Unhandled Exceptions Will Crash App **Severity:** CRITICAL **Location:** All components **Files Affected:** Entire application **Description:** No React Error Boundaries implemented anywhere. A single unhandled exception in any component will crash the entire application with a white screen of death. This is especially critical for a native desktop app. **Reproduction:** 1. Trigger any JavaScript error in a component 2. Entire app crashes with no recovery **Recommended Fix:** 1. Install `react-error-boundary` package 2. Wrap main app and major routes with ErrorBoundary components 3. Implement fallback UI with "Reload" button 4. Add error logging to Tauri backend Example implementation: ```tsx import { ErrorBoundary } from 'react-error-boundary'; function ErrorFallback({ error, resetErrorBoundary }) { return (

System Error

{error.message}
); } // Wrap routes ... ``` --- #### BUG-003: localStorage.clear() Destroys All User Data on Every App Load **Severity:** CRITICAL **Location:** `src/App.tsx:41` **Description:** The useEffect in App.tsx calls `localStorage.clear()` on EVERY app launch, destroying ALL user data including preferences, settings, and state. This is catastrophic for user experience. **Reproduction:** 1. Set any preference in the app 2. Close and reopen app 3. Virtual Scrolling **Problem:** Large lists (e.g., memory history) will cause performance issues. **Recommendation:** - Use `react-window` or `react-virtualized` for long lists - Implement infinite scroll for conversation history - Limit initial render to 50 items --- #### 4. Image Optimization **Problem:** Large PNG assets slow down load time. **Recommendation:** - Convert PNGs to WebP (50-80% smaller) - Use progressive loading for hero images - Implement lazy loading for off-screen images - Add blur placeholder for large images --- #### 5. payload.text:
**Assessing multi-language and multi-model chat support**

I'm focusing on the core module, especially `InteractionScreen`, which seems to handle chat for a single persona via `MimicBridge` without multi-language or multi-model group chat. The default language is English, shown in `src/voice/loop.py`, and there’s no UI or bridging support for multi-language or simultaneous multi-model interaction, so I’ll highlight these points with relevant file references.

payload.message:
- The “core” interaction surface is the per-persona chat page (`src/components/personas/screens/InteractionScreen.tsx`, lines 1‑39). It spins up one `MimicBridge` instance, maintains a single `conversationHistory` array, and renders only that persona versus the user. There’s no orchestration of multiple LLMs at once, no “group chat” layout, and no selector to add another model/persona into the same session; each preview is tied to the one `personaName` prop that’s passed in.  
- Voice/interaction helpers already default to English (`src/voice/loop.py`, lines 90‑107 call `transcribe(..., language="en")` and route the resulting text to the persona bridge), so there isn’t a built-in multi-language switch or translation pipeline for the interaction panel.  

Given those pieces, the core UI today only supports a single-persona chat in a single language; it doesn’t host a multi-model/group-chat experience with user-chat mix-ins out of the box.

It spins up one `MimicBridge` instance, maintains a single `conversationHistory` array, and renders only that persona versus the user. There’s no orchestration of multiple LLMs at once, no “group chat” layout, and no selector to add another model/persona into the same session; each preview is tied to the one `personaName` prop that’s passed in.  
- Voice/interaction helpers already default to English (`src/voice/loop.py`, lines 90‑107 call `transcribe(..., language="en")` and route the resulting text to the persona bridge), so there isn’t a built-in multi-language switch or translation pipeline for the interaction panel.  

Given those pieces, the core UI today only supports a single-persona chat in a single language; it doesn’t host a multi-model/group-chat experience with user-chat mix-ins out of the box.

## My request for Codex:
there's a major feature gap there, plus fully integrated voice seems absent as well.

payload.message:
## My request for Codex:
there's a major feature gap there, plus fully integrated voice seems absent as well.

- Confirmed the current core persona chat (`src/components/personas/screens/InteractionScreen.tsx:1`) is single-user, single-model; it instantiates one `MimicBridge`, keeps only that one `conversationHistory`, and renders user vs. that persona, so there’s no UI, state, or routing for multi-model/group-chat coordination or language switching out of the box.  
- Voice flow exists in the screen (mic toggle, TTS/sound buttons) but relies on the default `MimicBridge` + `VoiceMode` path with hard-coded English (`src/voice/loop.py:90-107`), so there’s no full multi-language voice pipeline nor any live capture/streaming beyond the initial stub; global voice integration is still missing.  
- Feature gaps you flagged can be addressed by designing a group chat container (allowing multiple persona cards, shared conversation history, language selectors) and wiring the voice bridge to actual multi-language transcription/TTS services, but that will require backend bridge work plus UI scaffolding to host the extra personas and language controls.

content.text:
- Confirmed the current core persona chat (`src/components/personas/screens/InteractionScreen.tsx:1`) is single-user, single-model; it instantiates one `MimicBridge`, keeps only that one `conversationHistory`, and renders user vs. that persona, so there’s no UI, state, or routing for multi-model/group-chat coordination or language switching out of the box.  
- Voice flow exists in the screen (mic toggle, TTS/sound buttons) but relies on the default `MimicBridge` + `VoiceMode` path with hard-coded English (`src/voice/loop.py:90-107`), so there’s no full multi-language voice pipeline nor any live capture/streaming beyond the initial stub; global voice integration is still missing.  
- Feature gaps you flagged can be addressed by designing a group chat container (allowing multiple persona cards, shared conversation history, language selectors) and wiring the voice bridge to actual multi-language transcription/TTS services, but that will require backend bridge work plus UI scaffolding to host the extra personas and language controls.

{"command":"cat <<'EOF' > docs/module_gap_analysis.md
# Module Gap Analysis

This companion to `docs/ui_recovery_plan.md` captures where the recovered mockups differ from the live module implementations, so we can prioritize which UI/feature pieces need to be reintroduced or redesigned in the preview workspace.

Each section outlines the shipped strengths, the largest *feature* gaps (missing capabilities or backend wiring), and the biggest *UI* gaps (missing layouts, controls, or interactive affordances that the mock promises).

## Core Module – `ProjectsDashboard`
- **Live implementation** (`src/components/core/ProjectsDashboard.tsx:1-80`) already provides project/kanban/gantt/risk tabs, CoreBridge data fetching, modals, and resource management controls.
- **Feature gaps**
  - No multi-persona or model-group chat surface; it never instantiates multiple namespaces or personas that the mock explorer implies when it calls out the navigator rail, persona chips, and global command timeline.
  - Navigation still tied to CoreBridge selections; there is no “open persona navigator” quick action or aggregated command stream defined in the UI yet.
- **UI gaps**
  - Mock hero (navigator rail, command timeline, persona chips) is absent from `ProjectsDashboard`; the page is a canonical dashboard without the chrome described in `ui_recovery/preview/module-data.js` or the chrome wrappers in TODO.
  - The aggregated “status ribbon + workspace canvas” layout described in the mock isn’t embodied by the current tab/pane layout, so the preview doesn’t show the same chrome or split preview detail panes.
- **Action items**
  - Align the mock hero with nav tabs by “porting” the navigator rail and command timeline into the preview and tying the action buttons to the existing CoreBridge handlers.
  - Reference `docs/ui_recovery_plan.md` for the chrome/token requirements before final reintegration.

## Alden Command Center – `AldenCommandCenter` & Email ensemble
- **Live implementation** (`src/components/alden/AldenCommandCenter.tsx:1-80`, `src/components/alden/EmailInbox.tsx:1-80`) supports tasks/events/email UIs, modals (CreateTask/Event, TaskDetail), keyboard shortcuts, and actual bridge calls for Alden, Calendar, and Email.
- **Feature gaps**
  - Mock lists “voice-level meter,” “intent tiles,” and “send to AldenBridge” without wiring to real voice services or transcript streaming; none of those controls surface actual audio inputs or Intent palette toggles.
  - Email mock mentions priority filters + persona suggestions, but the real `EmailInbox` already has account selection, quick actions, search, and proxies; yet the bridge actions (send, sync) are not accessible through the preview—they’re implied but not triggered.
- **UI gaps**
  - The mock’s “command transcript + secondary panel” layout, intentional palette, and voice-specific chrome aren’t mirrored; the live dashboard is more general and lacks the hero narrative from the mock data file.
  - Our preview still renders textual highlights rather than the multiple panels/voice meter/intent chips described in `ui_recovery/preview/module-data.js` (~ lines 35-70).
- **Action items**
  - Capture the Email+Calendar summaries into the preview canvas and surface the “voice level” plus “intent tiles” as interactive chips (even if still static) so reviewers can inspect the intended layout.
  - Keep the mock discrete from the real components while documenting the parity requirements (e.g., `AldenBridge` and voice gateway docs).

## Alice Mirror & Companion – `AliceDashboard`
- **Live implementation** (`src/components/alice/AliceDashboard.tsx:1-80`) fetches insights/profile via `AliceBridge`, renders Recharts visualizations, and manages loading/error/success states.
- **Feature gaps**
  - Preview lists “mood timeline + policy checklist,” but there is no visualization of the Recharts data or explicit policy sync toggles pulled from `AliceBridge`; the live dashboard already has charts but the mock lacks those shaped panels.
  - Policy approval controls are missing; AliceDashboard only consumes data without mock toggles for approvals/reflections described in the preview notes.
- **UI gaps**

## My request for Codex:
NOT multi-language voice gaps, I mean fully integrated with all systems.  The gap is that I don't see any kind of voice integration at all.

- Understood—what’s missing isn’t just multilingual toggles, it’s any live voice integration at all. ## Documentation Governance and Rules

### dYs" STRICT DOCUMENTATION RULES

#### 1. Single Source of Truth Principle
- **MANDATORY**: This `hearthlink_system_documentation_master.md` is the ONLY single source of truth for all Hearthlink documentation
- **FORBIDDEN**: Creating standalone documentation files without explicit reference in this master document
- **REQUIRED**: All documentation must be referenced in the Table of Contents below

#### 2. Documentation Creation Process
- **STEP 1**: Check if content fits existing appendix (A-Z) or requires new appendix
- **STEP 2**: If new appendix needed, assign next available letter (AA, etc.)
- **STEP 3**: Create appendix file with naming convention: `docs/appendix_[letter]_[descriptive_name].md`
- **STEP 4**: IMMEDIATELY update this master document's Table of Contents with new appendix reference
- **STEP 5**: Update the "Appendix References" section with new appendix details

#### 3. Documentation File Structure
- **ENFORCED**: All appendix files must follow naming convention: `docs/appendix_[letter]_[descriptive_name].md`
- **ENFORCED**: All appendix files must have proper header format matching the letter
- **ENFORCED**: All appendix files must include "Last Updated" date and "Updated By" information
- **ENFORCED**: All appendix files must reference this master document at bottom

#### 4. Documentation Updates
- **MANDATORY**: When updating any appendix, update the "Last Updated" date and "Updated By" information in appendix header
- **MANDATORY**: When updating any appendix, update the "Last Updated" date and "Updated By" information in master TOC reference
- **FORBIDDEN**: Making changes to appendix without updating master document reference
- **NEW RULE**: Always check if another agent has recently updated the documentation before making changes

#### 5. Agent Attribution and Coordination
- **MANDATORY**: All documentation updates must include the agent's name (e.g., "Updated by Claude", "Updated by AI")
- **MANDATORY**: Before overwriting any documentation, check the "Updated By" field to see who last modified it
- **REQUIRED**: If you intend to overwrite documentation recently updated by another agent, stop and ask questions first
- **REQUIRED**: Coordinate with other agents when working on related documentation to avoid conflicts

#### 6. Review Process
- **REQUIRED**: All new appendices must be reviewed by at least one other team member
- **REQUIRED**: All significant updates to existing appendices must be reviewed
- **REQUIRED**: Documentation review must include checking master document consistency
- **NEW RULE**: Check recent updates by other agents before making significant changes

#### 7. Obsolete Documentation
- **FORBIDDEN**: Creating new documentation that duplicates existing content
- **REQUIRED**: Update existing appendices rather than creating new ones
- **REQUIRED**: Mark obsolete appendices as "DEPRECATED" in master TOC before removal
- **REQUIRED**: Wait at least one sprint before removing deprecated appendices
- **NEW RULE**: Include agent attribution when deprecating documentation

#### 8. Documentation Quality Standards
- **MANDATORY**: All documentation must be clear, concise, and accurate
- **MANDATORY**: All documentation must use consistent terminology
- **MANDATORY**: All documentation must include examples where appropriate
- **MANDATORY**: All documentation must be properly formatted with markdown
- **NEW RULE**: Include attribution for all significant contributions

#### 9. Enforcement
- **MONITORING**: Regular audits will be conducted to ensure compliance with these rules
- **CORRECTION**: Any documentation found violating these rules will be corrected or removed
- **ACCOUNTABILITY**: These rules apply to all team members, including leadership
- **NEW RULE**: Agent attribution will be tracked to identify coordination issues

#### 10. Documentation Update Format
- **MANDATORY**: Use the following format for all updates:
  ```
  **Last Updated**: YYYY-MM-DD
  **Updated By**: [Agent Name]
  **Status**: [Current Status]
  ```
- **MANDATORY**: Include this format in both appendix headers and master document TOC references
- **REQUIRED**: Update both the "Last Updated" date and "Updated By" information when making changes

---

# Module Gap Analysis

This companion to `docs/ui_recovery_plan.md` captures where the recovered mockups differ from the live module implementations, so we can prioritize which UI/feature pieces need to be reintroduced or redesigned in the preview workspace.

Each section outlines the shipped strengths, the largest *feature* gaps (missing capabilities or backend wiring), and the biggest *UI* gaps (missing layouts, controls, or interactive affordances that the mock promises).

## Core Module - `ProjectsDashboard`
- **Live implementation** (`src/components/core/ProjectsDashboard.tsx:1-80`) already provides project/kanban/gantt/risk tabs, CoreBridge data fetching, modals, and resource management controls.
- **Feature gaps**
  - No multi-persona or model-group chat surface; it never instantiates multiple namespaces or personas that the mock explorer implies when it calls out the navigator rail, persona chips, and global command timeline.
  - Navigation still tied to CoreBridge selections; there is no "open persona navigator" quick action or aggregated command stream defined in the UI yet.
- **UI gaps**
  - Mock hero (navigator rail, command timeline, persona chips) is absent from `ProjectsDashboard`; the page is a canonical dashboard without the chrome described in `ui_recovery/preview/module-data.js` or the chrome wrappers in TODO.
  - The aggregated "status ribbon + workspace canvas" layout described in the mock isn't embodied by the current tab/pane layout, so the preview doesn't show the same chrome or split preview detail panes.
- **Action items**
  - Align the mock hero with nav tabs by "porting" the navigator rail and command timeline into the preview and tying the action buttons to the existing CoreBridge handlers.
  - Reference `docs/ui_recovery_plan.md` for the chrome/token requirements before final reintegration.

## Alden Command Center - `AldenCommandCenter` & Email ensemble
- **Live implementation** (`src/components/alden/AldenCommandCenter.tsx:1-80`, `src/components/alden/EmailInbox.tsx:1-80`) supports tasks/events/email UIs, modals (CreateTask/Event, TaskDetail), keyboard shortcuts, and actual bridge calls for Alden, Calendar, and Email.
- **Feature gaps**
  - Mock lists "voice-level meter," "intent tiles," and "send to AldenBridge" without wiring to real voice services or transcript streaming; none of those controls surface actual audio inputs or Intent palette toggles.
  - Email mock mentions priority filters + persona suggestions, but the real `EmailInbox` already has account selection, quick actions, search, and proxies; yet the bridge actions (send, sync) are not accessible through the preview-they're implied but not triggered.
- **UI gaps**
  - The mock's "command transcript + secondary panel" layout, intentional palette, and voice-specific chrome aren't mirrored; the live dashboard is more general and lacks the hero narrative from the mock data file.
  - Our preview still renders textual highlights rather than the multiple panels/voice meter/intent chips described in `ui_recovery/preview/module-data.js` (~ lines 35-70).
- **Action items**
  - Capture the Email+Calendar summaries into the preview canvas and surface the "voice level" plus "intent tiles" as interactive chips (even if still static) so reviewers can inspect the intended layout.
  - Keep the mock discrete from the real components while documenting the parity requirements (e.g., `AldenBridge` and voice gateway docs).

## Alice Mirror & Companion - `AliceDashboard`
- **Live implementation** (`src/components/alice/AliceDashboard.tsx:1-80`) fetches insights/profile via `AliceBridge`, renders Recharts visualizations, and manages loading/error/success states.
- **Feature gaps**
  - Preview lists "mood timeline + policy checklist," but there is no visualization of the Recharts data or explicit policy sync toggles pulled from `AliceBridge`; the live dashboard already has charts but the mock lacks those shaped panels.
  - Policy approval controls are missing; AliceDashboard only consumes data without mock toggles for approvals/reflections described in the preview notes.
- **UI gaps**
  - The mock's "reflection preview + checklist" layout isn't recreated; the preview shows cards, while `AliceDashboard` renders charts and lists text with no chrome matching the gradient/hints from `module-data` (lines ~60-110).
  - Visual similarity needs a connective tissue: palette, gradient overlays, and actual timeline/dancer components described in the mock should be sketched in the preview canvas.
- **Action items**
  - Sketch the mood timeline as gradient bars (maybe reuse the new visualizer panels) and annotate where the charts live in the real component for future walkthroughs.
  - Document the required attachments to `AliceBridge` and policy registry data so the preview identifies the missing wiring.

## Mimic Adaptation Studio - `MimicDashboard`
- **Live implementation** (`src/components/mimic/MimicDashboard.tsx:1-80`) loads personas via `MimicBridge`, toggles actives, opens persona modals, and keeps conversation edit states.
- **Feature gaps**
  - Mock mentions export widgets, transcript explorer, and behavior preview cards; the preview doesn't display any transcripts or export controls, and the real `MimicDashboard` only toggles persona cards without dedicated transcript views.
  - There's no "empathy score" or live behavior comparison built into the actual UI-those remain placeholders in the mock and in `module-data` (lines ~100-130).
- **UI gaps**
  - Preview visual canvas doesn't reflect the transcript explorer or comparison card layout; `MimicDashboard` is a list of persona cards and modals, so the preview needs additional canvas artifacts to show where transcripts/exports should go.
- **Action items**
  - Extend the preview with dedicated transcript + comparison panels and note how `MimicBridge` state should populate them once wiring exists.
  - Document expected inputs/outputs for export widgets so future reviewers know what to hook into after bridging.

## Vault & Secure Capture - `VaultDashboard`
- **Live implementation** (`src/components/vault/VaultDashboard.tsx:1-80`) handles encrypted memory creation, search, knowledge graph viewer integration, stats panels, and multiple modals tied to `VaultBridge`.
- **Feature gaps**
  - Mock describes "search + filter bar," "bridge health panel," and capture card grid meant for VaultBridge+encryption toggles, but the preview glosses over the knowledge graph view and secure capture cards present in `VaultDashboard`.
  - The actual search bar and stats are wired, yet the preview does not surface the real grid layout or capture quick actions (view/redact/export) described in the mock data (lines ~140-200).
- **UI gaps**
  - Knowledge graph and capture card grid (with security levels) are absent from the preview canvas; there is no representation of how the health panel ties into the `VaultBridge` heartbeat.
- **Action items**
  - Build preview panels for the search/filter bar plus capture cards and annotate them with the required bridge metrics (heartbeat, latency) for later integration testing.
  - Reference `docs/03_modules/vault/ui_spec.md` for token consistency when polishing the preview chrome.

## Synapse Integrations Hub - `SynapseDashboard`
- **Live implementation** (`src/components/synapse/SynapseDashboard.tsx:1-60`) fetches plugin/connection/security log data via `SynapseBridge` and exposes toggle handlers (plugin enable/disable) with success alerts.
- **Feature gaps**
  - Mock lists "connector grid," "event timeline," and "threat radar" (module-data lines ~200-240), but the preview only mentions them without rendering data. The real dashboard populates tables/lists, yet the preview lacks a visual analog to compare against.
  - There is no live "route to security" action or telemetry refresh UI described in the mock; those actions are placeholders with no backend triggers in the preview.
- **UI gaps**
  - The visual grid/timeline/radar described in the mock is not shown-no charts or radar pulses to match highlight cards, so reviewers can't confirm the visual treatment.
- **Action items**
  - Sketch widget outlines for connectors/timeline/radar and explain how they relate to `SynapseBridge` telemetry data.
  - Note that refresh/acknowledge actions need to tie back to `TelemetryRelay` or `SynapseBridge` once wiring is possible.

## Email & Inbox Control - `EmailInbox`
- **Live implementation** (`src/components/alden/EmailInbox.tsx:1-80`) already includes account selection, message filtering, compose form, sync button, keyboard shortcuts, and quick actions; it uses `useAldenBridge` to fetch/send messages.
- **Feature gaps**
  - Mock promises persona-aware composer suggestions and AI-assisted suggestion bar (module-data lines ~260-290), but the preview is static text; the real inbox lacks the AI suggestion drawer the mock mentions.
  - There is no persona hint overlay in the preview; the live component uses persona metadata, though the preview doesn't reflect that linkage.

# 1. Alden �?" Primary Local Agent/Persona

**Role:** Evolutionary Companion AI (Executive Function, Cognitive Partner, and Adaptive Growth Engine)

Alden is designed to learn and grow with each user, adapting his capabilities, personality, and guidance as the relationship matures.

- Executive function and productivity support, cognitive/developmental scaffolding, dynamic emotional and motivational feedback, habit- and relationship-aware memory and reasoning, progressive autonomy (user-controlled trust/delegation).
- All learning is local, transparent, and user-editable�?"no hidden memory, no external training.
- **Framework Provider**: Alden provides all framework and UI elements for task management, calendar management, time management, and email (IMAP, POP3)

---

## Technical Architecture

- **UI:** Growth/context/history adaptive. Radial Menu/Utility Strip exposes evolving skills/tools.
- **Screens:** 
  - **Hub** (dashboard/metrics/reflection)
  - **Cognition** (goals/tasks/habits)
  - **Interaction** (journal, reminders, nudges)
  - **Development** (skills/tutorials/co-pilot)
  - **Task Management** (comprehensive task tracking, prioritization, and workflow)
  - **Calendar Management** (scheduling, reminders, and integration)
  - **Time Management** (time tracking, focus sessions, and productivity analytics)
  - **Email Management** (IMAP/POP3 integration, email processing, and organization)
- **Frontend:** Next.js/React + Tailwind, component-driven.
- **Backend:** Vault integration (persona memory, learning data, session logs), all customizable.
- **State/Logic:** Session/user context hooks, notifications, context-aware logic for adapting visible UI/tools, all memory and learning are strictly local only.

---

## **Task Management Framework**

### Core Task Management Features
- **Task Creation & Organization**: Natural language task creation with automatic categorization
- **Priority System**: Dynamic priority adjustment based on user behavior patterns and deadlines
- **Workflow Management**: Customizable workflows with drag-and-drop interface
